info.headline: Extreme Fire Danger issued April 05 at 3:05AM MDT by NWS Sioux Falls
info.description: .DISCUSSION... Issued at 329 AM CDT Tue Apr 5 2022 TODAY: Biggest concerns today revolve on just how quickly the deeply mixed airmass moving off the Western Plains can slide eastward. High resolution guidance is a little bit slower this morning pushing this air eastward. Any rain that falls this morning may not limit fire danger given the 1-hr fuels won`t take long to dry back out. There is also some potential that temperatures may struggle to warm with the delay in arrival of dry air, and increased potential for afternoon cumulus field to develop. This could lead to higher relative humidity in the current red flag warning areas. That said, strong winds should negate the increased relative humidity potential and still lead to extreme danger. Given the slower and shortened duration of dry air advecting eastward, will hold off on any expansion of the current red flag warning but monitoring observations will be critical today. WEDNESDAY: Some light precipitation and cooler temps moving in Wednesday morning may lower fire danger risks slightly. However, I do have some concerns that we`ll see very strong gradient winds and some high end gusts. If mixing is deeper than expected and we can tap into a dry layer aloft, then dew points and relative humidity could drop further than forecast. Please be careful with fire...grass fires can move very quickly. ...EXTREME FIRE DANGER... The Grassland Fire Danger Index will reach the extreme category this afternoon. Extreme weather conditions and very low moisture content of grasses, and other dry organic material on the ground, indicate that critical burning conditions exist. All fires have the potential to become large and spread quickly, becoming erratic with extreme behavioral characteristics. No outdoor burning should take place. OUTLOOK FOR WEDNESDAY AFTERNOON...The Grassland Fire Danger Index will reach the extreme category. The grassland fire danger product reflects fire danger for native grasses. It is not intended for cured agricultural crops, nor will it reflect conditions in road ditches which have been mowed.
